facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 14 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 14 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against Bombay High Court judgment and order dated 24/26-9-1969 in Criminal Appeal No. 1825 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 24/26-9-1969 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1825 of 1965.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by Special Judge of Bombay under S. 165-A I.P.C. sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted by the Special Judge of Bombay under S. 165-A I.P.C. and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Bombay High Court upheld conviction but reduced imprisonment to six months.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court of Bombay upheld the companyviction but reduced the sentence of imprisonment to six months.

facts.text: Appellant is a partner of a firm owning New India Knitting Mills in Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a partner of a firm owning the New India Knitting Mills in Amritsar.

facts.text: J. D. Woollen and Silk Mills is sister concern owned by partnership where appellant's minor son is partner.

anchor.surface_text: It has a sister companycern called J. D. Woollen and Silk Mills, which is owned by a partnership firm of which the appellants minor son is a partner.

facts.text: On 10-10-1963 J.D. Mills given import licence for Rs. 23,480 for spare parts for Warp Knitting Machine from Germany.

anchor.surface_text: On 10-10-1963 the J. D. Mills was given an import licence for Rs. 23,480/- for spate parts for Warp Knitting Machine from Germany.

facts.text: Goods valued at Rs. 11,699 arrived in Bombay on 16.3.1964.

anchor.surface_text: Towards a part of that import licence goods valued at Rs. 11,699/- arrived in Bombay on 16.3.1964.

facts.text: J.D. Mills arranged clearance by New Suraj Transit Company with head office Amritsar and branch Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The J.D. Mills arranged for clearance of this companysignment by the New Suraj Transit Company having its head office in Amritsar and a branch in Bombay.

facts.text: Hiro Shahani, employee of clearing agents, became approver.

anchor.surface_text: One Hiro Shahani, who became an approver in this case, was an employee of the clearing agents.

facts.text: Bakubhai Ambalal Co. were representatives in India of the machinery manufacturing company.

anchor.surface_text: Bakubhai Ambalal Co. were the representatives in India of the machinery manufacturing companypany.

facts.text: Bill of Entry prepared on 4-6-1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill of Entry in respect of this companysignment was prepared on 4-6-1964.

facts.text: Motwani (PW6) examined consignment, opined not spare parts but machine in assembled condition.

anchor.surface_text: The companysignment was examined by ,one Motwani, who was later examined as P.W. 6 in the case. He was of opinion that the goods were number spare parts-but that it was a machine in assembled companydition.

facts.text: Shed Appraiser agreed with Motwani's view.

anchor.surface_text: The Shed Appraiser agreed with this view.

facts.text: Show cause notice issued on 17-7-1964 by Almeida for mis-declaration.

anchor.surface_text: Almeida approved of it on 9-7-1964 and on 17-7-1964 a numberice was accordingly issued by Almeida.

facts.text: Appellant reached Bombay on 1-7-1964.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-7-1964 the appellant reached Bombay.

facts.text: Appellant met Rao at Gaylord restaurant on 13-8-1964 and offered bribe of Rs. 5000.

anchor.surface_text: On 13-8-1964 the appellant met Rao at Gaylord. restaurant where Rao had gone to meet one of his companytact men. At that time the appellant is alleged to have made an offer of a bribe of Rs. 50001- to Rao.

facts.text: Rao reported bribe offer to Assistant Collector Sonavne at 1.30 p.m. on 13-8-1964.

anchor.surface_text: He duly reported the offer of bribe to his Assistant Collector, Sonavne at 1.30 p.m.

facts.text: On 14-8-1964 at Gaylord, appellant passed two envelopes containing Rs. 2,500 each to Rao, recovered by Jog.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse the appellant and Shahani came there. ... The appellant passed on two envelopes to Rao and at that moment Jog appeared on the scene and recovered both the envelopes from Rao. The envelopes were found to companytain Rs. 2,500/- each.

facts.text: Charge-sheet filed on 30-10-1964.

anchor.surface_text: The investigation was carried out and a charge-sheet filed on 30-10-1964.

facts.text: Shahani arrested on 24-11-1964, released on bail, statement in January 1965, confession before Magistrate on 19-3-1965, pardon granted after application on 15-4-1965.

anchor.surface_text: Shahani was arrested on 24-11-1964 and was released on bail. His statement was recorded in January 1965 by police and his companyfession statement before the Magistrate was ordered on 19-3-1965. On 15-4-1965 an application was made to grant him pardon...

facts.text: Shahani applied for reward on 21-5-1965, received Rs.500, Rs.500, Rs.350 on 7-6-1965.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on 21-5-1965 Shahani made an application to Customs Department for reward... and on 7-6-1965 he received 3 sums of Rs. 500, Rs. 500 and Rs. 350 as part payment of reward.

facts.text: Appellant denies meeting Rao on 13-8-1964, claims conspiracy between Rao and Shahani.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention on behalf of the appellant before us was that the meeting between Rao and the appellant on 13-8-1964 was number true, that this charge against him is the result of a companyspiracy between Rao and Shahani...

facts.text: Court finds appellant offered bribe on 13-8-1964 and gave bribe on 14-8-1964.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question is whether the appellant did make an offer of a bribe to Rao on 13-8- 1964 and did give the bribe on the 14th.

facts.text: Court satisfied that courts below correct in concluding guilt beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the companyclusion arrived at by both the, companyrts below about the appellants guilt is companyrect and it has been established beyond all reasonable doubt.

arguments.claim: The meeting between Rao and the appellant on 13-8-1964 did not take place and the charge is the result of a conspiracy between Rao and Shahani

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant before us was that the meeting between Rao and the appellant on 13-8-1964 was not true, that this charge against him is the result of a conspiracy between Rao and Shahani, the former with the object of advancing himself in his career by posing as an honest officer who refused an offer of a bribe and the latter with the sordid motive of getting reward as an informer, as also of getting a clearing agents licence

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the order of the learned Judge of the High Court permitting certain portions of the C.I.U. file to be brought on record was not correct. The learned Judge seems to have been more concerned with the provisions of section 125 than with section 124 of the Evidence Act.

arguments.claim: Even with CIU file evidence, prosecution case on bribe offer and payment not shaken; Shahani informer status does not affect merits

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the fact that Shahani had acted as an informer and applied for rewards for his services as an informer in respect of the 3 consignments imported by the J. D. Mills, in any way affects the merits of the prosecution case.

arguments.claim: No need to decide scope of court's power to examine documents under ss.123,124,125 Evidence Act as irrelevant to guilt

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for the purposes of this case to consider the scope of the powers of the court to examine the documents in respect of which privilege is claimed under ss. 123, 124 and 125 of the Evidence Act.

arguments.claim: Appellant met Rao on 13th and offered bribe; reported immediately making fabrication unlikely

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied on the evidence that the courts below were right in coming to conclusion that the appellant did meet Rao at Gaylord on the 13th. As we have already mentioned the appellant had immediately reported the matter to Assistant Collector, Sonavne

arguments.claim: Rao and Shahani lacked motive or means to falsely implicate with Rs.5000

anchor.surface_text: Nor could it be expected that either Shahani or Rao would have found Rs. 5,000/- merely to trap the appellant and risk that amount. There is no strong enough motive for either Shahani or Rao to implicate, the appellant falsely.

arguments.claim: Rao's evidence and panchnama consistent on substance; discrepancies due to memory lapse in crowded restaurant

anchor.surface_text: A witness is not like a tape-recorder. When he is giving evidence more than a year later about what happened a year earlier his memory may not serve him completely right. He may not be able to repeat the exact words used on the occasion or all the words.

arguments.claim: Appellant asked Shahani for papers on shipments but Shahani brought money envelopes instead

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to believe the appellants statement that when he asked Shahani to give Rao the papers in regard to the two consignments Shahani said he had got them outside and he would fetch them and he went out and brought two envelopes which were later found to contain currency notes.

arguments.court_reasoning: Implausible; papers would be with them inside; reaction not of innocent; consistent with postponing payment

arguments.claim: Appellant's reaction when caught not consistent with innocence; would have protested

anchor.surface_text: The reaction of the appellant when this happened was not that of an innocent person in such a situation. He would have burst out and abused Shahani. He would have come out with his case then and there.

arguments.claim: Bribe only to avoid harassment; reconsidered and wanted to pay after clearance showing reluctance

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we agree with the argument advanced on behalf of the appellant that Raos evidence to the effect that the appellant asked him whether he would be ready to accept money after the consignment was cleared shows that he had reconsidered his decision of bribing Rao and wanted to turn over a new leaf.

arguments.court_reasoning: Trying to have cake and eat it too; postponing payment; no harassment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rao's evidence reliable, corroborated by panchas and panchnama; discrepancies minor due to memory lapse; no motive for false implication; reaction inconsistent with innocence

holdings.text: We are satisfied on the evidence that the courts below were right in coming to conclusion that the appellant did meet Rao at Gaylord on the 13th

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied on the evidence that the courts below were right in coming to conclusion that the appellant did meet Rao at Gaylord on the 13th. As we have already mentioned the appellant had immediately reported the matter to Assistant Collector, Sonavne

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rao reported offer immediately to superiors; unlikely to fabricate without meeting; no strong motive for conspiracy

holdings.text: We are satisfied that on the substantial question as to what happened there is really no contradiction between the evidence of Rao and the panchnama statement as well as the evidence of the panch witnesses

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that on the substantial question as to what happened there is really no contradiction between the evidence of Rao and the panchnama statement as well as the evidence of the panch witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance consistent despite minor discrepancies attributable to crowded setting and memory lapse one year later

anchor.surface_text: Even if we accept this conclusion we do not consider that the imprisonment should be reduced below six months to which he reduced it. But we are of opinion that there was no harassment as the facts set out earlier would amply bear out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No harassment justified bribe; postponing payment shows no reluctance to bribe

holdings.text: We do not consider that this is a case like the one in Ramjanam Singh v. Bihar State of a person who had decided finally and firmly not to bribe
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes entrapment where accused firmly resolved not to bribe but provoked; here appellant initiated bribe

anchor.surface_text: Ramjanam Singh v. Bihar State 1  of a person who had decided finally and firmly number to bribe and where it companyld be said that he was deliberately tempted beyond the powers of his frail endurance and provoked into breaking the law by those who were the guardians and keepers of the law.

precedents.cited_proposition: a case of a person who had decided finally and firmly not to bribe and where it could be said that he was deliberately tempted beyond the powers of his frail endurance and provoked into breaking the law by those who were the guardians and keepers of the law

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the conclusion arrived at by both the courts below about the appellants guilt is correct and it has been established beyond all reasonable doubt. The only question that remains is the question of sentence. The learned Judge of the High Court has reduced the sentence of one years imprisonment awarded by the Special Judge to one of six months on the ground that the appellant paid the bribe only in order to avoid harassment. Even if we accept this conclusion we do not consider that the imprisonment should be reduced below six months to which he reduced it.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction under S. 165-A I.P.C. upheld; sentence reduced to six months rigorous imprisonment by High Court upheld, no further reduction.

We are satisfied that the conclusion arrived at by both the courts below about the appellants guilt is correct and it has been established beyond all reasonable doubt. The only question that remains is the question of sentence. The learned Judge of the High Court has reduced the sentence of one years imprisonment awarded by the Special Judge to one of six months on the ground that the appellant paid the bribe only in order to avoid harassment. Even if we accept this conclusion we do not consider that the imprisonment should be reduced below six months to which he reduced it.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the fact that Shahani had acted as an informer and applied for rewards for his services as an informer in respect of the 3 consignments imported by the J. D. Mills, in any way affects the merits of the prosecution case.

We are satisfied that the conclusion arrived at by both the courts below about the appellants guilt is correct and it has been established beyond all reasonable doubt. The only question that remains is the question of sentence. The learned Judge of the High Court has reduced the sentence of one years imprisonment awarded by the Special Judge to one of six months on the ground that the appellant paid the bribe only in order to avoid harassment. Even if we accept this conclusion we do not consider that the imprisonment should be reduced below six months to which he reduced it.
